summary: This is an email chain from March 2020 between FBI personnel discussing a potential witness. The emails reference records received from Interlochen Arts Academy showing Jeffrey Epstein paid the summer camp tuition for a specific student. The FBI agents discuss contacting this individual for an interview, noting she had previously appeared on a podcast discussing her dealings with Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the person who paid the summer camp tuition for a student at Interlochen Arts Academy.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Epstein; the potential witness discussed her dealings with Maxwell on a podcast.

connections.description: Mentioned together in the context of records and a podcast interview discussing dealings with them.

events.title: FBI email discussion about potential witness
events.description: FBI personnel exchange emails about contacting a former Interlochen student for an interview regarding her dealings with Epstein and Maxwell.

events.title: Epstein paid Interlochen tuition
events.description: Records indicate Jeffrey Epstein paid the summer camp tuition for a student at Interlochen Arts Academy during this period.

events.title: Podcast interview about Epstein and Maxwell
events.description: A former Interlochen student was interviewed on a podcast discussing her dealings with Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein.

keyFacts: Records from Interlochen Arts Academy show Jeffrey Epstein paid the summer camp tuition for a specific student between 1994 and 1998.
The FBI in March 2020 was seeking to interview this former student, who had appeared on a podcast discussing her dealings with Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell.
The email chain indicates FBI coordination to contact this potential witness, with one agent traveling to Aruba at the time.
The document references attached records including Epstein and Maxwell records, and Interlochen student declarations.
Multiple names and email addresses are redacted in the correspondence, indicating protected identities.
